column2: (7/7) Watching this all play out, it feels as though the world is conspiring to show Bitcoin‚Äôs value proposition on center stage. Like it or not, it seems we are entering a new age.

(6/7) The question is no longer whether these phenomena are real or where on earth they are happening but rather when, where, and to whom will they happen next, and why, and how many more people will be impacted, and how soon? 

It‚Äôs not ‚Äúif‚Äù. It‚Äôs ‚Äúwho‚Äôs next?‚Äù, and ‚Äúwhen?‚Äù.
(5/7) Today you can cite the US dollar, the Russian ruble and the truckers in Canada. Only you don‚Äôt need to. It‚Äôs all over the news, getting front page views.

(4/7) A few weeks ago, to cite tangible examples of high inflation, extreme devaluation, and asset freezing, you had to cite little known currencies like the Turkish lira and Venezuelan bol√≠var, and far away foreign events (from a western perspective) like the Hong Kong protests.
(3/7) The scarcity derived by its limited supply disables inflation and discourages devaluation while the censorship resistance prevents centralized abuses like asset freezing.
(2/7) Two of Bitcoin‚Äôs primary features are its programmed scarcity and censorship resistance, each enabled by its automation and decentralization.
(1/7) It‚Äôs crazy how the things that made Bitcoin ‚Äúclick‚Äù for me back when they seemed mostly hypothetical are now rapidly becoming actual in reality.

You have to say no to a lot of good opportunities so you can say yes to only the best.

Saying no to many good opps may feel unnatural and wrong. That‚Äôs because in a vacuum, it is. But you have to realize that in the scheme of things, it‚Äôs right.

Everything has opportunity cost.

Others just write. I have never really written at length with pen and paper, besides a couple minutes filling a page in a morning journal, but I'm sure this is valuable for those who do it as well. At least, it's probably a good way to start spending more time with pen and paper.

The things I tend to do with a pen and blank piece of paper are usually related to things like life design, idea development, goal setting, all things where an hour or two can (but certainly must not always) change my life for the better. It involves thinking and creativity.

Most people I know, including myself, spend at least 100x as much time on their computer as they do with a pen and blank piece of paper. I think many, including myself, could benefit from lessening that ratio from 100:1 or even just getting it to 100:1 (many are probably 1000:1).

This is an infinitely complex objective, and it as impossible to know how I am doing at any point in time as it is to know the future, but I am the only judge. All I can do is what I think is right, and have faith that it is, though I know I will never know. That‚Äôs what faith is.

For better or worse, I am obsessed with the objective of living my life in a way that I deem to be most worthwhile.

That is, importantly, ‚Äúmost worthwhile‚Äù by my ever-changing definition or lack thereof (instinct), not yours or anyone else‚Äôs, though they may influence mine.

@m_spilim Primarily, it is hard for some including myself to go to sleep early enough (9:30 or 10ish?) to get enough hours of sleep this way (depending on what you consider enough) and if you don‚Äôt, the trade off of being up so early vs. not getting enough sleep may well not be worthwhile.

One way to feel ahead of everyone around you on a daily basis is to rise before the sun.

Like forcing a smile can make you actually happy, feeling ahead in this way may get you actually ahead in others.

I‚Äôve been trying it more lately, 5:30. Pros and cons, but worth trying on.

Consider @beeple ‚Äòs 5000 days. Objectively prolific. Subjectively quality. Widely respected as a result. His collection goes for $69M.

Then consider the artist who spent the same time trying to perfect a few pieces over years, none if any ever ‚Äúdone‚Äù. You‚Äôve never heard of them.
Perfection is subjective. Prolificacy is objective.
The latter is impossible. The former is just hard.
Pursue prolificacy over perfection.

Btw this is not to say I think there's a good chance either BTC or ETH will fail, I don't, nor is this to say I don't think there's any chance of a monopolistic / power law distribution where one of these or another ends up with 90-99%+ of the total market cap, I do. Still...

If you really believed in decentralization, you would not be a maximalist of BTC, ETH, or any individual L1. One of the biggest negatives of centralization is that it has a single point of failure. If you have all your money in BTC, ETH or other, so do you. If it fails, you fail.

Btw I‚Äôm not advocating for saying ‚Äúno‚Äù to everything. I think it probably works for some people, but so does saying ‚Äúyes‚Äù to everything for others. 

More on that here: https://t.co/qh3mFwXvmh

Hall & Oates have a great song for people pleasers and yes men. 

If you‚Äôre bad at saying no, and you know it, the key is to keep it top of mind that you need and want to say ‚Äúno‚Äù more. Listen to their song once a day. I personally like this remix best: 

https://t.co/7Ax2tCYZrn

I don't have the answer here. I've read @sleepdiplomat and I've read @alexeyguzey. I've listened to @rabois. I've bought the @eightsleep bed and the @ouraring (podcast sponsor) and talked to both their CEOs. Still, I don't know. I could be very wrong. This is just a perspective.

Also, what does 8 hour even mean? It is important to define terms when miscommunication means many thousands of hours of life. Is it a 9 hour sleep window for ~8 hours of actual sleep or an 8 hour sleep window for ~7 hours of actual sleep (both assuming ~88% sleep efficiency)?

But, perhaps it is not. Perhaps it depends on the person. Probably, it does. Anyway I might think twice before accepting the common wisdom of 8 hours per night. You may not get anything but a trade of younger hours for older hours, if that, as that would imply lifespan extension.

Of course, there are many reasons 8 hours of sleep may be better than 6 hours of sleep. If you take my logic from the first two tweets to the extreme, a 2 hour sleeper gets many more hour young but probably dies young too and feels terrible the whole time. 6 hours could be bad.

Additionally, the 6 hour sleeper is taking the 8 hour sleeper's decade of hours awake from age 80 to 90 and trading them 1:1 for additional hours awake across ages 0-80 in this unrealistically clean but maybe reasonably proximate case. Most would prefer the younger hours I think.

365*80*(24-6) = 365*90*(24-8)

One view on sleep: whether you sleep 6 hours a night for 80 years or 8 hours a night for 90 years, you get 525,600 hours awake. So unless sleeping 8 vs 6 adds >12.5% to lifespan, or in this case 10 years (of 80), you get more hours awake sleeping 6.

@budries1 @ShortConsensus My understanding is that change of amendment requires 2/3 of house & senate so unlikely to flip back and forth (though agree changing once makes it more likely to change again). Only *maybe* feasible now bc left hates Trump more than they like Biden and right gains odds for 2024.

@budries1 @ShortConsensus Also fair. For me the idea was driven by desire to change incentives, not to block either individual. That said, I do think it is unusually feasible rn because of the immediate impact it would have blocking both from 2nd terms. So it may be good vs feasible for different reasons.

@ShortConsensus It certainly could. A lot of factors in play here many of which I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôve not thought of. One counter in favor of increased variance could say that the president should be changing faster than before to match the fact that the world around them is changing faster than before.

If you voted ‚Äúno‚Äù above I would love to know why in comments. 

One argument against would be that a lack of regard for re-election (if it was not possible regardless) could lead a leader to act more recklessly, with less accountability to the people.
I was just thinking, how might a president make decisions differently if we removed the overwhelming (arguably primary) incentive of seeking re-election?
Would you vote in favor of this?

What if @JoeBiden made it the priority of his presidency to rally the powers that be to push through an amendment to the 22nd Amendment?

The change would be to limit a president to only 1 term instead of 2, eliminating the possibility of another term for either himself or Trump.

...Then I realized that was just an excuse to excuse myself from being as audacious as the pre-teen Jobs. I realized emails are better than phone numbers in many respects, and even though there's no email book, almost anyone's can be found. Who's your Bill Hewlett? Reach out now.

12-year old Steve Jobs found Bill Hewlett's number in the phone book and cold called the HP co-founder to ask for some spare parts. He ended the call 20 mins later with an internship. I thought it was so lucky that you used to be able to find anyone's number in the phone book...

It used to be easy to answer how many hours you worked per week. It was just how many hours you spent in the office, including breaks of all sorts of course, plus hours (if any) worked outside it. Now it‚Äôs a much harder question, but easy to realize the old answer was very wrong.

I woke up at 5:40 and couldn‚Äôt fall back to sleep so I went down to my desk to work.

I woke up at 5:40 feeling good, energized and ready to go so I started getting after it before the sun came up.

2 different ways of saying/thinking the same thing.

Choose the positive version.
